abstract.t: An extension to POP3 allowing opened connections to be shelved, avoiding the const of repeated TCP and TLS handshakes when polling for new messages and for message deletes to be committed without having to disconnect.

section.title: Introduction
section.t: When polling for new messages in a POP3 mailbox, both client and server need to repeatedly re-negotitate TCP and TLS and re-authenticate every time the client attempts to poll for new messages. By allowing a client to keep an underying connection open instead of closing it down, the client is at liberty to resume using the opened connection at a later time and so avoid the burden of all the steps needed to reconnect.

This document specifies an extension that enables this mode of operation. It introduces a new SLEEP state, alongside the established states, with commands to enter and leave this new state. During the SLEEP state, the client remains authenticated and the underlying connection remains open, but the associated mailbox is unlocked and inaccessable.
The underlying connection that remains open includes the TLS channel if present, including if that channel was opened by an explicit STLS command or implied by use of TCP port 995.

Furthermore, the command to leave the TRANSACTION state and enter SLEEP will also commit any pending message deletes made with the DELE command that would otherwise only be committed at the QUIT command.

POP3 is designed to work on a simple bulk-download-and-delete model, eschewing more advanced features such as folder management. This extension is compatible with that model as the high-level operation of client and server is unchanged, only adding the ability to shelve an opened connection between polls.

section.title: Requirements Language
section.t: The key words "MUST", "MUST NOT", "REQUIRED", "SHALL", "SHALL NOT", "SHOULD", "SHOULD NOT", "RECOMMENDED", "MAY", and "OPTIONAL" in this document are to be interpreted as described in RFC 2119.

section.title: Capability
section.t: A service implementing this extension indicates support by including the capability "SLEEPING" in response to a CAPA command.

list.t: SLEE in TRANSACTION, WAKE in SLEEP
The SLEEPING capability indicates the optional SLEE and WAKE commands are available and the SLEEP state is supported.

section.title: The SLEEP State
section.t: This RFC introduces the SLEEP state, alongside the established states of AUTHORIZATION, TRANSACTION and UPDATE. An opened connection enters the SLEEP state on a +OK success response to a SLEE command and leaves it on a +OK response to a WAKE or QUIT command.
During the SLEEP state, the server MUST support these commands: NOOP, QUIT, WAKE.

list.t: NOTE: This document STRONGLY encourages that during a sleep state, service implementations return error responses to any command other that the three listed above. This will assist those developing clients from wrongly assuming commands such STAT or UIDL could be used during a SLEEP state to poll for new messages.

NOTE: This document STRONGLY encourages those services that place a lock on a mailbox during a TRANSACTION state to release those locks during a SLEEP state and allow other concurrent requests. It is permitted for the WAKE command to fail with a "-ERR [INUSE]" failure response if a separate connection has taken the lock for the mailbox during the SLEEP state.

section.title: Considerations for other capabilities
section.t: "CAPA" is not on the list of commands that are valid to use during the SLEEP state.

Registered capabilities include a statement to which states each capability may be announced in, often using "both" as a shorthand for "both the AUTHOIZATION and TRANSACTION states". As this document does not introduce a new state when the CAPA command may be used, this document does not change the meaning of the capabilities registered.

section.title: The SLEE Command
section.t:
The POP3 SLEE command requests that the POP3 service take the following steps:
All actions that take place on a successful QUIT command and UPDATE state, except for closing down the channel over which commands and responses are sent and received.
The connection transitions to the SLEEP state.
If the service cannot perform these steps, it MUST return an error (-ERR) response and leave the state of the mailbox and opened connection unchanged.

On the succesful completion of the SLEE command including successful transition to the SLEEP state, the service MUST respond with a success response (+OK) to indicate to the client it's request was succesful. A client MUST wait for a response before sending additional commands, regardless of the PIPELINING capability.

list.t: NOTE: Messages flagged for deletion by DELE are finally deleted by the SLEE command as well as by the QUIT command. Other POP3 extensions might allow for a mailbox to be modifed, but similar to DELE, the modification is documented to be diferred until committed by a QUIT command. In this case, those modifications would be committed by the SLEE command too. The only difference between SLEE is QUIT is that with SLEE, the communciations channel, including TCP and TLS, remain open.
